Award.AwardTitle: Theoretical Investigation of Strong Field Processes for Advancing Attosecond Chemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research studies how electrons of an atom or molecule react to intense laser fields and to each other. Strong laser fields are used to study electron dynamics at the attosecond (10^-18 s) timescale for applications such as solar energy conversion and photosynthesis. Previous studies have assumed that only one electron is active in these systems. However, experiments have now shown that the interaction of many electrons, both with each other and with the field must be included. This project will attempt to include these effects. In addition, this project will provide two undergraduate students and one graduate student a broad array of theoretical and computational training. As part of the project, computations that yield useful information on attosecond chemistry will be incorporated into the curriculum for the undergraduate advanced physical chemistry class. Collaborations with experimentalists and quantum chemists involved in the project will contribute to building the connection between conventional spectroscopy and the emerging attosecond chemistry.

The focus of this investigation will be the suppressed ionization of transition metal atoms vanadium, nickel, niobium, palladium, and tantalum in intense laser fields, and spectral features of high harmonic generation (HHG) for argon, nitrogen, and the molecule NO. The features include Cooper minima and HHG enhanced by resonances. There will be extensive benchmarking that consists of comparisons with published results and among different conditions, which will provide insight into the time-dependent density functional theory (TDDFT) approach and methods to improve it as well. The proposed study will render the most probable ion state, the form of the out-going electron wave function, and the time-dependent exchange and correlation potentials. This knowledge will lead to new understanding and improved modeling of strong field many-electron dynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Strong field physics is a rapidly progressing science that advances attosecond technology. The subject of attosecond chemistry needs theoretical developments that connect strong field phenomena to many-electron dynamics that usually accompanies a chemical process. Unfortunately, the established strong field theory relies on the single active electron (SAE) approximation.  This award supported a series of studies on the tunneling ionization of transition metal atoms and ions, with which we discovered and analyzed strong-field many-electron effects,  identified processes that involve multiple orbitals, and  created as well as benchmarked computational methods that resolves many-electron interactions in intense laser fields. These efforts paved the way for probing chemical processes with subfemtosecond resolution.

An important finding is the nature of the Legendre components of the induced many-electron potential, which has a far-reaching impact on the tunneling ionization of many-electron systems, which in turn influences the processes that involve rescattering, including high harmonic generation and non-sequential double ionization. As shown in the figure, only the zero and first order components are significant. The zeroth order component is isotropic and attractive, which keeps the electron closer to the core and the zeroth order component increases the tunneling barrier. Both factors reduce the tunneling ionization of neutral transition metal atoms, i.e., the tunneling probability is lower than the prediction of an SAE model. We also find that when the highest electron is subject to a greater exchange interaction, which is the case for a high spin state, the induced potential is more attractive near the core and repulsive at the peak of the barrier. As such the energy of the high spin state is lowered more in the field and the ionization barrier is raised higher, which leads to "exchange blockade". This finding may be materialized in technologies for measuring exchange interactions.
 
Calculating the induced many-electron potential is crucial in determining the ionization probabilities, as well as providing insights into the effects of many-electron interactions. Our time-dependent density functional theory (TDDFT) calculations agree well with the experimental measurements for vanadium and nickel. They are consistent with the observation that the exchange interaction tends to suppress tunneling. They also reproduce the trend that, as the charge increases, the ionization yield of the cation becomes less suppressed and more enhanced relative to the SAE prediction.

In addition to the induced potential from the time-dependent calculations, the orbital energies from our static DFT calculations also correlate with the impact of many-electron effects on the tunneling ionization. The highest electron of a neutral transition metal atom occupies an s-orbital. Observing Koopmans' theorem, the calculated orbital energy agrees well with the ionization potential (Ip). If there is a second electron that occupies the same s-orbital, however, the Ip for removing which turns out to be greater than the negative of the orbital energy. This is due to the rearrangement other electrons that accompanies the ionization and the exchange interaction with this second electron is greater.

For most of the transition metal cations, a d-orbital is the highest occupied one. In this case the Ip becomes lower than the absolute value the orbital energy, suggesting that it takes less energy to ionize than predictions of an SAE model, which is consistent with experimental data of higher ionization yields.  Data analysis demonstrates that, for the cations, the tunneling electron occupies an s- instead of a d-orbital, which means a proceeding excitation. The additional centrifugal barrier of d-orbitals is the cause of this excitation, which has further implication in probing transition metal chemistry and calls for a continued investigation.

Two graduate students and four undergraduate students have participated in this project. For the undergraduate students, the research activity helped them to understand the subject of quantum chemistry, which is relatively new to them. In addition, this was their first computational experience.  They learned about numerical convergence, as well as how to analyze data and make presentations. The graduate students performed method developments and  trained the undergraduate students for using computer programs.  This project also helped the PI to bring components of computation into the undergraduate chemistry curriculum.
